thread.title: NASA's Retro 1970s Style Guide Released

title: NASA's Retro 1970s Style Guide Released
text:
Sponsored By NASA's Retro 1970s Style Guide Released Some have speculated that the move is an attempt to thwart two designers who are charging $79 for a printed version of the manual. 13:40, UK, Thursday 10 September 2015 The style guide shows designers how astronaut outfits should look Pic: NASA Share by email The 1970s graphics manual which once influenced how NASA designed everything from pants to planes has been released. 
The document explains how the agency's logo and typeface should be used on astronaut uniforms and space shuttles. 
Then-administrator Richard H Truly wrote in the documents introduction that it was a "new tool to enhance and symbolise the progressive path we have always followed". 
Illustrations of plans, trucks and the space shuttle are included with how the various strands of NASA branding should be used. The guide details how branding on the space shuttle should look. Pic: NASA 
The manual is the document that introduced NASA's "worm" logo - with the letters made up of thick lines. 
No formal announcement or news release was issued to accompany the newly uploaded document. 
However many people have speculated that the move is an attempt to thwart two New York-based designers who created a Kickstarter to reproduce the manual in print. 
Designers Jesse Reed and Hamish Smyth have been working with Richard Danne - one of the creators of the old NASA logo which was phased out in 1992. The document introduced NASA's "worm" logo. Pic: NASA 
For $79, Kickstarter backers can reserve hard copies of the manual, complete with a foreword from Mr Danne. 
Mr Reed hit back at NASA's apparent attempt to thwart his moneymaking plan. 
He said: "From what we see, they are scanning the pages rather quickly and without much consideration for reproduction value. 
"Our scans will be much higher quality, perfectly colour balanced, and include the matching spot colours specified in the manual (among other signature elements) - something you don't really understand through a digital representation."
